head.title: Do You Hear What I Hear?

hedline.hl1: Do You Hear What I Hear?

block.p: Re ''When You Meet an Imus,'' by Bob Morris (Age of Dissonance, April 22):

As a criminal defense attorney, dealing with racial prejudice is important in jury selection. I was taught to ask a series of questions about prejudice and bias: Ever heard an ethnic joke? Ever told one, or have one told about your ''kind'' while you were present? The follow-up questions about what they might have thought about it and why they picked on a particular group, led to other questions: When you heard it, and didn't like it, did you say anything about it? When you said it, did anyone tell you it wasn't funny?
Re ''When You Meet an Imus,'' by Bob Morris (Age of Dissonance, April 22):

As a criminal defense attorney, dealing with racial prejudice is important in jury selection. I was taught to ask a series of questions about prejudice and bias: Ever heard an ethnic joke? Ever told one, or have one told about your ''kind'' while you were present? The follow-up questions about what they might have thought about it and why they picked on a particular group, led to other questions: When you heard it, and didn't like it, did you say anything about it? When you said it, did anyone tell you it wasn't funny?

The answers I got from the overwhelmingly white, older jury -- this was in an upstate rural county, and cases involved black state-prison inmates mostly from New York City -- provoked much discussion and, I believe, opened the eyes of potential jurors to the insidious nature of how prejudice can infect our lives. And by being a little more aware, I think we were able to select fairer and less-biased jurors.
